awd_titl_txt: Predation, Competition, and Establishment Dynamics within an Insular Adaptive Radiation
awd_abstract_narration:
Adaptive radiation occurs when a single species invades a new environment (for example, an island) and subsequently diversifies into many species, each specialized to thrive in a particular segment of that new environment. Current understanding of adaptive radiation emphasizes the importance of resource scarcity and competition as the engine of diversification; in contrast, the role of predators in promoting or inhibiting such rapid bursts of evolution is largely unknown. This research will lead to better understanding of how competition and predation interact to (a) determine whether closely related species can coexist (a prerequisite for adaptive radiation), and (b) shape the subsequent evolutionary trajectories of those species. This experiment will improve science relevant to invasive-species management, which in in the national interest. This project also involves innovations in STEM education that will strengthen the scientific workforce. 

Competition for limiting resources has long been thought to be the primary driver of adaptive radiation, and is the foundation for existing theory, but predation may play an equally important role in mediating species coexistence and diversification within adaptive radiations. This project focuses on the classic Anolis lizard adaptive radiation, using whole-ecosystem manipulations on 16 small Caribbean islands to assess how predation by curly-tailed lizards (Leiocephalus carinatus) affects competitive interactions between an established resident lizard species (Anolis sagrei) and experimentally introduced populations of a more arboreal lizard species (Anolis smaragdinus). Population trends, behavioral responses, diet composition, and genetic and morphological changes of all three lizard populations will be monitored. Molecular diet analysis (including isotopic analyses), radio-telemetry, and genomics (RAD-tag and RADseq sequencing) will be used to quantify variables, which will be tested for interaction and differences using standard and Bayesian statistical methods.  Broader impacts include illumination of mechanisms underlying the success or failure of invading populations on islands, and the development of an undergraduate course combining interdisciplinary (including humanities) and field-based approaches.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how species become established in new environments, and the consequences of such colonization events, is a fundamental goal in ecology and evolutionary biology. The distribution of biodiversity across the planet is the result of countless dispersal, establishment, and extinction events. The outcome of these events—whether an invading species becomes established or not, and for how long—can determine the evolutionary trajectory of that species and the ecological trajectory of the invaded ecosystem. Successful invasions can lead to the proliferation of life forms, when founders become isolated from their parent population and adapt to the new environment, but they are also a leading cause of extinction. These events also have tremendous economic implications. In the United States alone, invasive species are estimated to cause more than $100 billion in damages each year, and hundreds of millions more are spent on prevention and mitigation efforts.

The aims of this research were to understand what determines the invasion success of species colonizing island ecosystems; to document the ecological and evolutionary effects of these invasions on resident species; and to test general theories about the rules that govern the diversity and distribution of life. To do this, we performed a controlled invasion experiment on 16 small Bahamian islands. On these tiny islands, brown anole lizards were the resident species atop the food chain. The experiment involved introducing a competing anole species (the green anole), a top predator (the curly-tailed lizard), both the competitor and the predator, or neither. We subsequently monitored the populations, behaviors, and diets of each lizard species (to track ecological changes); the morphology and genomes of the resident brown anoles (to track evolutionary changes); and the diversity of insects and spiders (which all three lizards eat). This approach enabled us to study invasions at realistic scales and in real time, with experimental control and replication, which is rarely possible. We combined the experiment with cutting-edge molecular assays to glean insight into the causal basis of the observed dynamics.

Our research led to a number of new discoveries. First, we discovered epigenetic signatures associated with the colonization of new environments. Epigenetic changes alter the expression of genes and are therefore one way in which organisms can cope with the physiological stress of inhabiting new environments; indeed, we found that these epigenetic changes were strongest in environmentally stressful conditions. Second, we found that top predators regulate invasion success. On islands without top predators, green anole lizards successfully invaded and coexisted with brown anoles; on islands without top predators, green anoles failed to establish. We showed how this outcome resulted from shifts in the behavior and diet of each lizard species. When top predators were present, both anole species crowded into safe arboreal habitat where the predators could not reach them; there, they ate the same insects, leading to strong competition and the local extinction of introduced green anoles. These findings advance our general understanding of the mechanisms that regulate not just invasion success, but also species coexistence and diversity more broadly. Third, we found that introduced lizard populations did not dramatically depress the overall diversity of insects and spiders, but did influence which species persisted. We obtained this result using a novel method for collecting and sequencing environmental DNA from rocks and vegetation, a technique that can be applied for various purposes elsewhere (including the early detection of invasive insect pests). Fourth, we showed that resident brown anole lizard populations evolved in response to the species introductions, but that these genetic and morphological changes were not predictable in advance despite a wealth of supporting background knowledge. While underscoring the capacity for rapid evolution in response to biological invasions, these results also show that the specific evolutionary trajectories are difficult to anticipate. In addition to these main findings, our work contributed to methodological advances and progress on a number of conceptually related research efforts.

Collectively, this research advanced knowledge about the causes and consequences of species invasions, the maintenance of species diversity, the structure of food webs, the predictability of evolution, and the methods scientists can use to better understand these things. Project data are publicly available without restriction and include contributions to several global databases. The research was communicated to the public in news articles, press releases, blog posts, a short YouTube film, and a documentary feature film. The project supported mentorship and career development for more than a dozen undergraduate and graduate students, along with several postdoctoral trainees.
